text.p: Lithuanian newspapers carried the following reports in their Thursday editions. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy:

- The Lithuanian parliament intends to pass a law on Thusday to compensate people whose savings were devoured by hyper-inflation in 1990-1991. The finance minister said that 3.2 billion litas would be necessary and the funds will be raised by the privatisation of state property.
- The famous German musician and conductor Justus Frantz will conduct the Philharmonie der Nationen orchestra in Vilnius tonight.
- Dutch justice officials said that they have good reason to believe that illegal drugs from Pakistan are being channeled to Western Europe from the Lithuanian port of Klaipeda.
- The share capital of Lithuania's Savings Bank will be boosted by 20 million litas to 80 million litas.
- The governor of the Bank of Lithuania, Reinoldijus Sharkinas, said that the central bank intends to impose stricter supervision on commercial banks.
- Lithuanian Gas said that a hike in natural gas prices is necessary if it is to post a profit this year.

- U.S. environmental bureaucrat Valdas Adamkus topped the most recent opinion poll concerning December's presidential race conducted by Baltic Surveys. President Algirdas Brazauskas was second, followed by former prosecutor general Arturas Paulauskas and the chairman of parliament, Vytautas Landsbergis.
- The press office of parliamentary chairman Vytautas Landsbergis said on Wednesday that rumours that the ruling Homeland Union Party wants to oust the central bank chief are groundless.
- The Holy Father founded the seventh Lithuanian diocese in Siauliu and appointed three new Lithuanian bishops on Wednesday.
- Tibet foreign minister in exhile T.C.Tethong visits Lithuania to meet the Tibet support group in Lithuania's parliament.
